subject: Shavian-to-QS transcriber and thoughts on Shavian/Quikscript unification

messageBody:
After an afternoon's work I've managed to push some Quikscript things onto my website. While the main QS page at <http://www.frogorbits.com/qs/> doesn't mention anything that's new to read-discuss habitués, I did put up a Shavian-to-Quikscript converter that's available at <http://www.frogorbits.com/qs/from-shavian/>*. With it, I was finally able to read "The Evolution of Words for Zero" at <http://groups.yahoo.com/group/shawalphabet/message/3297> (force your browser to display as UTF-8 for the proper Shavian to show up).

---

I'd like to note in passing that this made the difference between not understanding and understanding both the "The Evolution of Words for Zero" and the excerpt from _Journey to the Center of the Earth_ by Verne. Kingsley Read transposed some of the sound/letter associations, and figuring out the swaps isn't easy at all:

- Shavian's 𐑔 makes a [T] sound, but a seemingly-identical letter in Quikscript makes an [f] sound
- ditto for Shavian 𐑞 ([D]), a [v] sound in Quikscript
- Shavian's 𐑥 is for [m], but in QS it's [A]
- Shavian's 𐑯 is for [n], but in QS it's for [O]

In Quikscript the diphthongs are made with some kind of slant (top to bottom or bottom to top) with a loop on either the top or the bottom. Figuring out how these translate to Shavian isn't easy:

- I don't see any relationship between 𐑬 ([aU]) and its QS counterpart
- I don't see any relationship between 𐑱 ([eI]) and its QS counterpart
- I don't see any relationship between 𐑲 ([aI]) and its QS counterpart
- I don't see any relationship between 𐑶 ([OI]) and its QS counterpart

Finally, the -r ligatures don't always make sense from a QS perspective:

- 𐑻 bears no apparent relationship to 𐑳 or 𐑩
- the non-𐑮 part of 𐑺 doesn't look like anything else — so which vowel is it supposed to be?


Back on April 20, in <http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/message/2449>, John Cowan wrote:

> On the question of unification, it would be extremely useful if
> you could prepare a short document showing the same passage in
> both scripts, similar to your Coptic/Greek/Cyrillic document at
> <http://www.evertype.com/standards/cy/coptic.html>. My general feeling
> is that the structural correspondences are not enough and that legibility
> demands disunification, but seeing is believing.

<http://www.frogorbits.com/qs/from-shavian/> does just that.

Hopefully these difficulties are sufficient to convince the UTC that it'd be best for Quikscript users to have a block of code points that aren't shared with Shavian.




* For some reason Chrome screws up the Quikscript bits. I don't know why — I suspect it's, in part, due to some of the things that Font Squirrel does. I think Chrome works just fine if I feed it the .otf. At any rate, Firefox and IE 8+ display it without error.
